messageBody:
Ben Maurer wrote:
> I thought @RunWith was optional and that you did not have to set it on
> all classes with tests

It is optional: leaving it off gives you the default TestClassRunner,
which is likely what you want.

> > It seems to me that stack filtering is a user interface responsibility.
> > Every time we get into the formatting business we regret it (see
> > ComparisonFailure for an example).
>
> I don't think user programs have the knowledge needed to do this. For
> example, if I have a junit test like junit's one that actually
> executes junit inside the test, it will screw up. Also, because of the
> timeout behavior, we'll introduce stuff from java.util.concurrent
> into the trace, which means we have to figure out *exactly* which
> methods there need excluding. In general, this is fragile. JUnit can
> easily get a stack trace from the method that calls user-code. This
> would at least allow a tool to find out exactly what frames needed to
> be killed.

I'll look at it a bit more. The concern is that the same issues that
make this difficult and fragile for runner clients would make it
difficult for us to get right in JUnit.

David Saff
